content.raw:
Is there a plan to provide fancier API's using the `FreeGroupFrameSemantics` feature? Like the following:

*  `FreeGroup::SetRelativePose(RelativePose)`
*  `FreeGroup::SetRelativeLinearVelocity(RelativeLinearVector)`
*  `FreeGroup::SetRelativeAngularVelocity(RelativeAngularVector)`

If so, then perhaps we should put `World` in the features that set World pose and velocity:

* `SetFreeGroupPose` -> `SetFreeGroupWorldPose`
* `SetFreeGroupVelocity` -> `SetFreeGroupWorldVelocity`

I think we could save the fancy API's for later, but I want to make sure we like the names for the features we're adding now
content.html:
Is there a plan to provide fancier API's using the FreeGroupFrameSemantics feature? Like the following:

  • FreeGroup::SetRelativePose(RelativePose)
  • FreeGroup::SetRelativeLinearVelocity(RelativeLinearVector)
  • FreeGroup::SetRelativeAngularVelocity(RelativeAngularVector)

If so, then perhaps we should put World in the features that set World pose and velocity:

  • SetFreeGroupPose -> SetFreeGroupWorldPose
  • SetFreeGroupVelocity -> SetFreeGroupWorldVelocity

I think we could save the fancy API's for later, but I want to make sure we like the names for the features we're adding now

content.raw: +1 for `FreeGroup::SetRelative*` functions.
content.html: +1 for FreeGroup::SetRelative* functions.

content.raw: I would recommend an API like `FreeGroup::SetPose(RelativePose)`, because I would expect "set relative pose" to mean "set this as the value of the `FreeGroup`'s pose relative to its parent" which has a very different meaning than what I think you’re intending.
content.html: I would recommend an API like FreeGroup::SetPose(RelativePose), because I would expect "set relative pose" to mean "set this as the value of the FreeGroup's pose relative to its parent" which has a very different meaning than what I think you’re intending.

content.raw: Oh, but I see what you mean. Yes, we can rename the feature to `SetFreeGroupWorldPose` and have the functions that accept relative poses as a separate feature.
content.html: Oh, but I see what you mean. Yes, we can rename the feature to SetFreeGroupWorldPose and have the functions that accept relative poses as a separate feature.

content.raw:
I think it would be valuable to define what a `FreeGroup` is. Does it map directly to a single skeleton (ie. a connected group of links not connected to the world, with a FreeJoint in dart)? Or can there be multiple skeletons / unconnected free links? I think it will help clarify the meaning of `Model::FindFreeGroup` and `Link::FindFreeGroup` if we define `FreeGroup` better.

Initially, I assumed a `FreeGroup` had to be connected, such that a model with multiple skeletons would have multiple free groups. Of course, the way `Model::SetWorldPose` works in osrf/gazebo is that it acts on multiple connected groups of links, so it's helpful to create functions that support that use case. I think it could be clarified a bit.
content.html:
I think it would be valuable to define what a FreeGroup is. Does it map directly to a single skeleton (ie. a connected group of links not connected to the world, with a FreeJoint in dart)? Or can there be multiple skeletons / unconnected free links? I think it will help clarify the meaning of Model::FindFreeGroup and Link::FindFreeGroup if we define FreeGroup better.

Initially, I assumed a FreeGroup had to be connected, such that a model with multiple skeletons would have multiple free groups. Of course, the way Model::SetWorldPose works in osrf/gazebo is that it acts on multiple connected groups of links, so it's helpful to create functions that support that use case. I think it could be clarified a bit.

content.raw: if we are trying to refer to a model that has no links that are externally constrained, maybe we should just called it a `FreeModel`?
content.html: if we are trying to refer to a model that has no links that are externally constrained, maybe we should just called it a FreeModel?

content.raw:
to provide an analog for `Model::SetWorldPose`, I think a `FreeModel` entity would make sense

while for `Link::SetWorldPose`, I think a `FreeGroup` would make sense, but then you should be able to query how many `FreeGroup`s are in a model and get them by index
content.html:
to provide an analog for Model::SetWorldPose, I think a FreeModel entity would make sense

while for Link::SetWorldPose, I think a FreeGroup would make sense, but then you should be able to query how many FreeGroups are in a model and get them by index

content.raw:
Related to [this description](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/85/add-prototype-of-freegroup-features/activity#comment-100074959), the `FreeGroup` concept is meant to be an abstraction for a set of links which, as long as they are moved in sync with each other, can be moved anywhere without violating any joint constraints.

That set of links may be an entire model or a subset of a model. Which one it will be depends on how the user asked for it to be constructed. But once it's constructed, it's just a set of bodies that can be moved in sync with each other without violating any constraints. The API shouldn't care about whether it's a whole model \(`FreeModel`\) or a subset of a model; I think that's an unnecessary distinction to make for the concept that's being exercised.
content.html:
Related to this description, the FreeGroup concept is meant to be an abstraction for a set of links which, as long as they are moved in sync with each other, can be moved anywhere without violating any joint constraints.

That set of links may be an entire model or a subset of a model. Which one it will be depends on how the user asked for it to be constructed. But once it's constructed, it's just a set of bodies that can be moved in sync with each other without violating any constraints. The API shouldn't care about whether it's a whole model (FreeModel) or a subset of a model; I think that's an unnecessary distinction to make for the concept that's being exercised.

content.raw: Incidentally, I'd be very open to a feature that allows multiple `FreeGroup` instances to be merged into one, although that would complicate the implementation of the `FreeGroup` entity because the plugin would then have to keep track of which sets of `FreeGroup` instances have been requested by the user \(in the current implementation, the `FreeGroup` just borrows the entity ID of the link or model  that it’s constructed from\).
content.html: Incidentally, I'd be very open to a feature that allows multiple FreeGroup instances to be merged into one, although that would complicate the implementation of the FreeGroup entity because the plugin would then have to keep track of which sets of FreeGroup instances have been requested by the user (in the current implementation, the FreeGroup just borrows the entity ID of the link or model that it’s constructed from).

content.raw: I could be wrong, but I think a skeleton can have multiple kinematic trees that are not connected to each other so it is directly analogous to a gazebo model (perhaps with the exception of nesting). In my understanding, a `FreeGroup` can represent a connected group of links that forms a tree and where the root of the tree is connected to the world with a `FreeJoint`. A `FreeGroup` can also represent a group of other `FreeGroup`s, in which case, applying `SetWorldPose` the parent `FreeGroup` would apply the the transform to each child `FreeGroup` while making sure the relative pose between each child `FreeGroup` remains unchanged.
content.html: I could be wrong, but I think a skeleton can have multiple kinematic trees that are not connected to each other so it is directly analogous to a gazebo model (perhaps with the exception of nesting). In my understanding, a FreeGroup can represent a connected group of links that forms a tree and where the root of the tree is connected to the world with a FreeJoint. A FreeGroup can also represent a group of other FreeGroups, in which case, applying SetWorldPose the parent FreeGroup would apply the the transform to each child FreeGroup while making sure the relative pose between each child FreeGroup remains unchanged.

content.raw:
I've been testing the `FreeGroup` feature in ign-gazebo. I think `SetPose` and `SetVelocity` work pretty well if the model only has one free group. 

**Set pose repeatedly:**

![resized.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/5q9rMzd/images/808586229-resized.gif)

**Set angular velocity**

![setangvel_resized.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/5q9rMzd/images/1968619923-setangvel_resized.gif)

For a model with two free links, i.e. two free groups, the `SetPose` works if the links are at rest. 

**Set pose repeatedly:**

![setpose.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/5q9rMzd/images/4183667358-setpose.gif)

**Set angular velocity**

![angular_vel.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/5q9rMzd/images/330325357-angular_vel.gif)

If you want to try it out, checkout the` move_entity` branch of ign-gazebo, build, and run the example in `example/worlds/move_entity.sdf`. The move-entity system subscribes to a `cmd_pose` and `cmd_vel` for each model and link. Once the simulation starts, you can run the following commands:

* For commanding pose on a model `ign topic -t "/model/box/cmd_pose" -m ignition.msgs.Pose -p "position: {y: 1.0 z: 2.5}"`
* For commanding velocity on a model `ign topic -t "/model/box/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 0 y: 1.0 z: 2.5} angular: {z: 1}"`
* For commanding pose on a link `ign topic -t "/model/box/link/box_link/cmd_pose" -m ignition.msgs.Pose -p "position: {y: 1.0 z: 2.5}"`
* For commanding velocity on a model `ign topic -t "/model/box/link/box_link/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 0 y: 1.0 z: 2.5} angular: {z: 1}"`
content.html:
I've been testing the FreeGroup feature in ign-gazebo. I think SetPose and SetVelocity work pretty well if the model only has one free group.

Set pose repeatedly:

Set angular velocity

For a model with two free links, i.e. two free groups, the SetPose works if the links are at rest.

Set pose repeatedly:

Set angular velocity

If you want to try it out, checkout themove_entity branch of ign-gazebo, build, and run the example in example/worlds/move_entity.sdf. The move-entity system subscribes to a cmd_pose and cmd_vel for each model and link. Once the simulation starts, you can run the following commands:

  • For commanding pose on a model ign topic -t "/model/box/cmd_pose" -m ignition.msgs.Pose -p "position: {y: 1.0 z: 2.5}"
  • For commanding velocity on a model ign topic -t "/model/box/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 0 y: 1.0 z: 2.5} angular: {z: 1}"
  • For commanding pose on a link ign topic -t "/model/box/link/box_link/cmd_pose" -m ignition.msgs.Pose -p "position: {y: 1.0 z: 2.5}"
  • For commanding velocity on a model ign topic -t "/model/box/link/box_link/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 0 y: 1.0 z: 2.5} angular: {z: 1}"

content.raw:
I'm having trouble running the examples, because `ign-gazebo` seems to be killing itself a short while after the debug line

```
[GUI] [Dbg] [gui_main.cc:186] Requesting list of world names. The server may be busy downloading resources. Please be patient.
```

It seems to be happening on all the world files that I try to load, so I’m guessing I’ve checked out the wrong branch of some ignition package.

That being said, I think the `Set pose repeatedly` for two free groups is working as intended. If you watch it closely, the moment before the faded box “disappears”, it has wound up in a pose that is far “beneath” \(has a significant negative z value in\) the frame of the bright red box. I think what’s happening is the faded box ends up underneath the ground plane, which makes it seem like it’s disappeared, but in reality it’s probably either falling off to negative infinity, getting launched into outer space, or getting stuck in the ground depending on how the extreme violation of the plane collision constraint is being handled.

It seems to be happening on all the world files that I try to load, so I’m guessing I’ve checked out the wrong branch of some ignition package.

That being said, I think the Set pose repeatedly for two free groups is working as intended. If you watch it closely, the moment before the faded box “disappears”, it has wound up in a pose that is far “beneath” (has a significant negative z value in) the frame of the bright red box. I think what’s happening is the faded box ends up underneath the ground plane, which makes it seem like it’s disappeared, but in reality it’s probably either falling off to negative infinity, getting launched into outer space, or getting stuck in the ground depending on how the extreme violation of the plane collision constraint is being handled.

content.raw:
For the record, the `SetAngularVelocity` function behaves differently from Gazebo classic when a model contains multiple unconnected kinematic trees. In Gazebo classic, doing `Model::SetAngularVel` on the `box` model from the example above (move_entity.sdf) causes the two boxes to just rotate about their own axis without any linear velocity whereas calling `FreeGroup::SetAngularVelocity` on the model FreeGroup applies both linear and angular velocities to the non-canonical link. 

**Gazebo classic:**

![classic_setangvel.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/5q9rMzd/images/2990982215-classic_setangvel.gif)

vs** Ign-gazebo**

![setangvel.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/5q9rMzd/images/330325357-angular_vel.gif)
content.html:
For the record, the SetAngularVelocity function behaves differently from Gazebo classic when a model contains multiple unconnected kinematic trees. In Gazebo classic, doing Model::SetAngularVel on the box model from the example above (move_entity.sdf) causes the two boxes to just rotate about their own axis without any linear velocity whereas calling FreeGroup::SetAngularVelocity on the model FreeGroup applies both linear and angular velocities to the non-canonical link.

Gazebo classic:

vs Ign-gazebo

content.raw:
My personal opinion is that Gazebo Classic is “wrong” here \(using a subjective form of “wrong”\), because Gazebo Classic is not altering the angular velocity of the model, but rather altering the angular velocity of each link individually.

That behavior is likely to result in states that egregiously violate the joint constraints and may be hard for ODE or other maximal coordinate physics engines to recover from.

The new behavior ensures that users can’t ask for joint constraints to be violated, which should help keep simulations sane and stable.
content.html:
My personal opinion is that Gazebo Classic is “wrong” here (using a subjective form of “wrong”), because Gazebo Classic is not altering the angular velocity of the model, but rather altering the angular velocity of each link individually.

That behavior is likely to result in states that egregiously violate the joint constraints and may be hard for ODE or other maximal coordinate physics engines to recover from.

The new behavior ensures that users can’t ask for joint constraints to be violated, which should help keep simulations sane and stable.

content.raw:
Agreed that Gazebo classic's implementation isn't what one would expect when setting the model's velocity.

@azeey and I also talked a bit IRL about calling the function `SetInstantaneousVelocity` instead, so it's clear that the velocity is not persistent.
content.html:
Agreed that Gazebo classic's implementation isn't what one would expect when setting the model's velocity.

@azeey and I also talked a bit IRL about calling the function SetInstantaneousVelocity instead, so it's clear that the velocity is not persistent.

content.raw:
While I agree that osrf/gazebo is wrong to not consider joint constraints when setting angular velocity, I think the example @azeey posted is slightly different because the model has two free boxes. You can see in the bottom animation that calling SetAngularVelocity gives a large linear velocity to one of the boxes, causing them to fly apart, which seems more wrong to me that the top animation.

I think setting the angular velocity of each FreeJoint without also setting linear velocity would still honor kinematic constraints but wouldn't cause models to fly apart.
content.html:
While I agree that osrf/gazebo is wrong to not consider joint constraints when setting angular velocity, I think the example @azeey posted is slightly different because the model has two free boxes. You can see in the bottom animation that calling SetAngularVelocity gives a large linear velocity to one of the boxes, causing them to fly apart, which seems more wrong to me that the top animation.

I think setting the angular velocity of each FreeJoint without also setting linear velocity would still honor kinematic constraints but wouldn't cause models to fly apart.

I'll clarify; I don't think it's a matter of right and wrong, it's more a matter of utility. I can't imagine ever wanting to use the behavior shown in the bottom animation, which would cause the model to fly apart, while I could imagine having a model with a bunch of spheres on a table (no joints) and warning to make them all spin in place (like the top animation). I think the following would give this behavior:

diff -r f2a83cc66c18 dartsim/src/FreeGroupFeatures.cc
--- a/dartsim/src/FreeGroupFeatures.cc  Thu May 02 13:25:05 2019 -0700
+++ b/dartsim/src/FreeGroupFeatures.cc  Fri May 03 18:59:40 2019 -0700
@@ -169,20 +169,14 @@

   const Eigen::Vector3d delta_w =
       _angularVelocity - info.link->getAngularVelocity();
-  const Eigen::Vector3d origin = info.link->getTransform().translation();

   for (std::size_t i = 0; i < info.model->getNumTrees(); ++i)
   {
     auto *bn = info.model->getRootBodyNode(i);
-    const Eigen::Vector3d r = bn->getTransform().translation() - origin;
-    const Eigen::Vector3d v = bn->getLinearVelocity();
-    const Eigen::Vector3d w = bn->getAngularVelocity();
+    const Eigen::Vector3d new_w = bn->getAngularVelocity() + delta_w;

-    dart::dynamics::FreeJoint *fj =
-        static_cast<dart::dynamics::FreeJoint*>(bn->getParentJoint());
-
-    fj->setLinearVelocity(v + delta_w.cross(r));
-    fj->setAngularVelocity(w + delta_w);
+    static_cast<dart::dynamics::FreeJoint*>(bn->getParentJoint())
+        ->setAngularVelocity(new_w);
   }
 }

content.raw: we can resolve this when adding tests
content.html: we can resolve this when adding tests

content.raw:
I have the complete opposite view. I think if someone wants to represent many unconstrained objects as being part of a single “model” instead of many individual models, then that strongly implies that they want those objects to act as a cohesive unit in some way. Otherwise why wouldn’t they just create many models and set the velocities individually?

For example, someone might want to represent a swarm of objects in one model and set the velocity of the overall swarm coherently so that everything remains in sync.

And even in your example, a user can still accomplish what they want with the current behavior; they just need to loop through the links, get a FreeGroup for each link, and set the velocity of each link’s FreeGroup. The cost of obtaining a FreeGroup for an unconstrained root link is hardly anything \(it’s effectively just one string comparison to identify that the parent joint is a FreeJoint\), so performance isn’t really a concern.
content.html:
I have the complete opposite view. I think if someone wants to represent many unconstrained objects as being part of a single “model” instead of many individual models, then that strongly implies that they want those objects to act as a cohesive unit in some way. Otherwise why wouldn’t they just create many models and set the velocities individually?

For example, someone might want to represent a swarm of objects in one model and set the velocity of the overall swarm coherently so that everything remains in sync.

And even in your example, a user can still accomplish what they want with the current behavior; they just need to loop through the links, get a FreeGroup for each link, and set the velocity of each link’s FreeGroup. The cost of obtaining a FreeGroup for an unconstrained root link is hardly anything (it’s effectively just one string comparison to identify that the parent joint is a FreeJoint), so performance isn’t really a concern.

content.raw: For your swarm application example, are you imagining that they would call `SetAngularVelocity` at every timestep? If you don't do that, I think everything would fly apart and certainly not remain in sync.
content.html: For your swarm application example, are you imagining that they would call SetAngularVelocity at every timestep? If you don't do that, I think everything would fly apart and certainly not remain in sync.

content.raw:
If it’s being used to control the swarm then yes, it would need to be called at every timestep.

However, I would always strongly discourage “controlling” anything by directly modifying the state. Instead I would envision the initial velocity of the swarm being set using this function.
content.html:
If it’s being used to control the swarm then yes, it would need to be called at every timestep.

However, I would always strongly discourage “controlling” anything by directly modifying the state. Instead I would envision the initial velocity of the swarm being set using this function.

content.raw:
I think I would also propose a feature called `GetFreeGroupEntities`, which would have the following functions:

~~~
std::size_t GetFreeGroupCount() const // get number of links with FreeJoints in this FreeGroup
FreeGroupPtrType GetFreeGroup(std::size_t) // get one of the embedded singular FreeGroups
// likewise with ConstFreeGroupPtrType
std::size_t GetLinkCount() const // get number of links in this FreeGroup
LinkPtrType GetLink(std::size_t) // get link by index
// likewise with ConstLinkPtrType
~~~

but it could wait for a later pull request
